xxl.core.indexStructures.builder.BPlusTree

Class BPlusConfiguration.Creator

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.indexStructures.builder.IndexConfiguration
      • xxl.core.indexStructures.builder.BPlusTree.BPlusConfiguration
        • xxl.core.indexStructures.builder.BPlusTree.BPlusConfiguration.Creator
  • Enclosing class:
    BPlusConfiguration

    public static class BPlusConfiguration.Creator
extends BPlusConfiguration
    A concrete implementation of IndexConfiguration for setting up the requirements of a BPlusTree according to your needs. With an object of BPlusTreeConfiguration type you can define whatever your BPlusTree should be kept in memory or stored on the hard drive, the block size (in Byte), the buffer size, the needed Containers and which table schema you want to manage including a set of key which should be used for the indexing job. If you don't make the use of any setter methods a BPlusTree with the following configuration will be created by default:
    • The block size used it set to 4096 Bytes (4 KB)
    • A single (unshared) LRUBuffer with size of 20 items is used
    • The converter container is a MapContainer
    • The tree will be kept in main memory
    • The first column of your table will be the (single) index key
    If you want to change this configuration just use the corresponding setter methods.

    Note: Ensure that there is no index out of bounds when setting up a compounded key, see ResultSetMetaData behavior for attribute index design in contrast to "normal" item index of e.g. an array. Please note that the first item index is one not zero for table columns.
    See Also:
    Easily build a BPlus tree with a given BPlusTreeConfiguration, The base class for all index configurations, The BPlus tree index structure itself

    • Constructor Detail

      • Creator

        public Creator(ManagedType primitiveType)
        Constructs a new BPlusTreeConfiguration.

        Example 
         TupleMetaData myTupleMetaData = new TupleMetaData("Students", new ColumnMetaInfo [] {
 new ColumnMetaInfo (RelationalType.INTEGER, "ID")
 new ColumnMetaInfo (RelationalType.VARCHAR, 20, "name")});
 
 BPlusTreeConfiguration configuration = new BPlusTreeConfiguration(new TupleType(myTupleMetaData));
        Parameters:
        primitiveType - The meta data for your table which should be managed
        See Also:
        TupleMetaData, ManagedType

      • getContentType

        public String getContentType()
        Returns the content type of the data managed by the tree. This is a string which represents the type of data. The string starts with "primitive/" (for primitive types) or "complex/" (for e.g. tuples) followed by a identifier.
        Returns:
        the current content type
        See Also:
        ManagedType.getContentType()

        Note: Because this only used by the BPlus tree builder the visibility of this method is restricted to package wide visibility.
        Returns:
        the given meta data

      • setBuffer

        public BPlusConfiguration.Creator setBuffer(Buffer buffer)
        Sets the buffer used for the BPlus tree. By default it is a single (unshared) LRUBuffer with a capacity of INDEX_REQUIREMENTS_DEFAULT_LRU_BUFFER_SIZE items. When setting a new buffer feel free to use a shared buffered for multiple trees.
        Parameters:
        buffer - A buffer which should be used by the BPlus tree
        Returns:
        The current BPlusTreeConfiguration instance including the effect of this method call. With this it is possible to set the configuration in one single line like 
        BPlusTreeConfiguration con = new BPlusTreeConfiguration(..).setA().setB()...
         instead of setting each property in a single call like 
          BPlusTreeConfiguration con = new BPlusTreeConfiguration(..);
  con.setA();
  con.setB();
  ...

      • setCompoundKey

        public BPlusConfiguration.Creator setCompoundKey(int... compoundKeyIndices)
        Set the indices of the column which should be used as the compounded key for indexing. The tuples are compared lexicographically in descending order of their key indices given by compoundKeyIndices. The order of the table columns is the order in which you define it in compoundKeyIndices array. Thus, the first column (according to the first array item value) is compared with the first column of another tuple (according to the first array item value).

        If there is more than one key column, lets say two, the second columns are compared if there is equality in the first column for both tuples.

        Please mark that e.g. a compoundKeyIndices array [1,2] first compares the first column and after this (if necessary) the second column. Whereas [2,1] forces to compare at first the second column and after this (if necessary) the first column. Here, it must be ensured that the components of a tuple, which form a key, have to be comparable and also that there will be no duplicate values for a (compounded) key, so that a (compounded) key uniquely identifies a tuple.

        Please note: The first column has the index one not zero whereas the first array item has the index zero.
        Parameters:
        compoundKeyIndices - An array that contains the column indices. Please note that the order of the columns matters for comparing and that each column index is in bounds of the table column count.
        Returns:
        The current BPlusTreeConfiguration instance including the effect of this method call. With this it is possible to set the configuration in one single line like 
        BPlusTreeConfiguration con = new BPlusTreeConfiguration(..).setA().setB()...
         instead of setting each property in a single call like 
          BPlusTreeConfiguration con = new BPlusTreeConfiguration(..);
  con.setA();
  con.setB();
  ...

  con.setB();
  ...

      • storeAt

        public BPlusConfiguration.Creator storeAt(String storeDir)
        If you want to store the BPlus tree on a persistent storage instead of the default main memory usage you have to set a directory path in which the BPlus tree stores it's files. Please ensure that storeDir is a valid and accessible directory on the file system. If it is necessary from the perspective of BPlus tree to write down the data there will be a couple of files generated including a single file which contains the given meta data information. The file name is taken from the table name given in meta data when calling the constructor. The file extensions depends on the content and will be managed by the BPlus tree itself.
        Parameters:
        storeDir - A valid and accessible directory at the hard drive or network storage.
        Returns:
        The current BPlusTreeConfiguration instance including the effect of this method call. With this it is possible to set the configuration in one single line like 
        BPlusTreeConfiguration con = new BPlusTreeConfiguration(..).setA().setB()...
         instead of setting each property in a single call like 
          BPlusTreeConfiguration con = new BPlusTreeConfiguration(..);
  con.setA();
  con.setB();
  ...

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Prints the content of this configuration into a string. It contains
        • The block size
        • File path where the tree should be stored
        • A flag which indicates if the tree should be hold in main memory or at hard drive
        • The content type
        • The table name
        If the tree should manage tuples instead of primitive data types there are some additionally information printed
      • The compound key indices
      • A dump of all column meta data
